senseval2.d000.s000: The art of change-ringing is peculiar to the English , and , like most English peculiarities , unintelligible to the rest of the world .
senseval2.d000.s001: Dorothy L. Sayers , `` The Nine Tailors ``
senseval2.d000.s003: Of all scenes that evoke rural England , this is one of the loveliest : An ancient stone church stands amid the fields , the sound of bells cascading from its tower , calling the faithful to evensong .
senseval2.d000.s004: The parishioners of St. Michael and All Angels stop to chat at the church door , as members here always have .
senseval2.d000.s005: In the tower , five men and women pull rhythmically on ropes attached to the same five bells that first sounded here in 1614 .
senseval2.d000.s006: But there is also a discordant , modern note in Aslacton , though it can not be heard by the church-goers enjoying the peal of bells this cool autumn evening .
senseval2.d000.s007: Like most of the other 6,000 churches in Britain with sets of bells , St. Michael once had its own `` band `` of ringers , who would herald every Sunday morning and evening service .
senseval2.d000.s008: Now , only one local ringer remains : 64-year-old Derek Hammond .
senseval2.d000.s009: The others here today live elsewhere .
senseval2.d000.s010: They belong to a group of 15 ringers -- including two octogenarians and four youngsters in training -- who drive every Sunday from church to church in a sometimes-exhausting effort to keep the bells sounding in the many belfries of East Anglia .
senseval2.d000.s011: `` To ring for even one service at this tower , we have to scrape , `` says Mr. Hammond , a retired water-authority worker . ``
senseval2.d000.s012: We 've tried to train the youngsters , but they have their discos and their dances , and they just drift away . ``
senseval2.d000.s013: Mr. Hammond worries that old age and the flightiness of youth will diminish the ranks of the East Anglian group that keeps the Aslacton bells pealing .
senseval2.d000.s014: History , after all , is not on his side .
senseval2.d000.s015: According to a nationwide survey taken a year ago , nearly a third of England 's church bells are no longer rung on Sundays because there is no one to ring them .
senseval2.d000.s016: It is easy to see why the ancient art is on the ropes .
senseval2.d000.s017: The less complicated version of playing tunes on bells , as do the carillons of continental Europe , is considered by the English to be childish , fit only for foreigners .
senseval2.d000.s018: Change-ringing , a mind-boggling exercise the English invented 380 years ago , requires physical dexterity -- some bells weigh more than a ton -- combined with intense mental concentration .
senseval2.d000.s019: Proper English bells are started off in `` rounds , `` from the highest-pitched bell to the lowest -- a simple descending scale using , in larger churches , as many as 12 bells .
senseval2.d000.s020: Then , at a signal , the ringers begin varying the order in which the bells sound without altering the steady rhythm of the striking .
senseval2.d000.s021: Each variation , or change , can occur only once , the rules state .
senseval2.d000.s022: Ringers memorize patterns of changes , known as `` methods , `` which have odd-sounding names like Kent Treble Bob Major or Grandsire Caters .
senseval2.d000.s023: A series of 5,000 or so changes is a `` peal `` and takes about three hours .
senseval2.d000.s024: A look at a Thursday night practice at St. Mary Abbot church in the Kensington district of London gives an idea of the work involved .
senseval2.d000.s025: Ten shirt-sleeved ringers stand in a circle , one foot ahead of the other in a prize-fighter 's stance , each pulling a rope that disappears through a small hole in the high ceiling of the ringing chamber .
senseval2.d000.s026: No one speaks , and the snaking of the ropes seems to make as much sound as the bells themselves , muffled by the ceiling .
senseval2.d000.s027: Totally absorbed , the ringers stare straight ahead , using peripheral vision ( they call it `` rope-sight `` ) to watch the other ropes and thus time their pulls .
senseval2.d000.s028: Far above in the belfry , the huge bronze bells , mounted on wheels , swing madly through a full 360 degrees , starting and ending , surprisingly , in the inverted , or mouth-up position .
senseval2.d000.s029: Skilled ringers use their wrists to advance or retard the next swing , so that one bell can swap places with another in the following change .
senseval2.d000.s030: In a well-known detective-story involving church bells , English novelist Dorothy L. Sayers described ringing as a `` passion that finds its satisfaction in mathematical completeness and mechanical perfection . ``
senseval2.d000.s031: Ringers , she added , are `` filled with the solemn intoxication that comes of intricate ritual faultlessly performed . `` ``
senseval2.d000.s032: Ringing does become a bit of an obsession , `` admits Stephanie Pattenden , master of the band at St. Mary Abbot and one of England 's best female ringers .
senseval2.d000.s033: It is a passion that usually stays in the tower , however .
senseval2.d000.s034: More often than not , ringers think of the church as something stuck on the bottom of the belfry .
senseval2.d000.s035: When their changes are completed , and after they have worked up a sweat , ringers often skip off to the local pub , leaving worship for others below .
senseval2.d000.s036: This does not sit well with some clerics .
senseval2.d000.s037: With membership of the Church of England steadily dwindling , strong-willed vicars are pressing equally strong-willed and often non-religious ringers to attend services .
senseval2.d000.s038: Two years ago , the Rev. Jeremy Hummerstone , vicar of Great Torrington , Devon , got so fed up with ringers who did n't attend service he sacked the entire band ; the ringers promptly set up a picket line in protest .
senseval2.d000.s039: `` They were a self-perpetuating club that treated the tower as sort of a separate premises , `` the Vicar Hummerstone says .
senseval2.d000.s040: An entirely new band rings today at Great Torrington , several of whom are members of the congregation .
senseval2.d000.s041: But there still are not enough ringers to ring more than six of the eight bells .
senseval2.d000.s042: At St. Mary 's Church in Ilminster , Somerset , the bells have fallen silent following a dust-up over church attendance .
senseval2.d000.s043: The vicar , W.D. Jones , refuses to talk about it , saying it would `` reopen the wound . ``
senseval2.d000.s044: But C.J.B. Marshall , vicar of a nearby church , feels the fault is in the stairs from the bell tower that are located next to the altar .
senseval2.d000.s045: `` So crunch , crunch , crunch , bang , bang , bang -- here come the ringers from above , making a very obvious exit while the congregation is at prayer , `` he says .
senseval2.d000.s046: Vicar Marshall admits to mixed feelings about this issue , since he is both a vicar and an active bell-ringer himself .
senseval2.d000.s047: `` The sound of bells is a net to draw people into the church , `` he says .
senseval2.d000.s048: `` I live in hopes that the ringers themselves will be drawn into that fuller life . ``
senseval2.d000.s049: The Central Council of Church Bell Ringers , a sort of parliament of ringing groups , aims to improve relations with vicars , says John C. Baldwin , president .
senseval2.d000.s050: It hopes to speak to students at theological colleges about the joys of bell ringing and will shortly publish a booklet for every vicar in the country entitled , `` The Bells in Your Care . ``
senseval2.d000.s051: Says Mr. Baldwin , `` We recognize that we may no longer have as high a priority in church life and experience . ``
senseval2.d000.s052: Mr. Baldwin is also attacking the greater problem : lack of ringers .
senseval2.d000.s053: One survey says that of the 100,000 trained bellringers in England today , only 40,000 of them still ring .
senseval2.d000.s054: Also , ringers do not always live where the bells need to be rung -- like in small , rural parishes and inner-city churches .
senseval2.d000.s055: But the council 's program to attract and train ringers is only partly successful , says Mr. Baldwin .
senseval2.d000.s056: `` Right now , we 're lucky if after five years we keep one new ringer out of 10 , `` he adds .
senseval2.d000.s057: One bright sign is that a growing number of women have entered the once male-dominated field ; more than a third of the ringers today are women .
senseval2.d000.s058: They are not accepted everywhere , however .
senseval2.d000.s059: The oldest bell-ringing group in the country , the Ancient Society of College Youths , founded in 1637 , remains male-only , a fact that 's particularly galling to women because the group is the sole source of ringers for Britain 's most prestigious churches , St. Paul 's Cathedral and Westminster Abbey .
senseval2.d000.s060: This being Britain , no woman has filed an equal-opportunity suit , but the extent of the problem surfaced this summer in a series of letters to `` The Ringing World , `` a weekly newspaper for ringers .
senseval2.d000.s061: One writer , signing his letter as `` Red-blooded , balanced male , `` remarked on the `` frequency of women fainting in peals , `` and suggested that they `` settle back into their traditional role of making tea at meetings . ``
senseval2.d000.s062: In the torrent of replies that followed , one woman ringer from Solihull observed that `` the average male ringer leaves quite a lot to be desired : badly dressed , decorated with acne and a large beer-belly , frequently unwashed and unbearably flatulent in peals . ``
senseval2.d000.s063: Another women wrote from Sheffield to say that in her 60 years of ringing , `` I have never known a lady to faint in the belfry .
senseval2.d000.s064: I have seen one or two men die , bless them .
senseval2.d001.s000: Medical scientists are starting to uncover a handful of genes which , if damaged , unleash the chaotic growth of cells that characterizes cancer .
senseval2.d001.s001: Scientists say the discovery of these genes in recent months is painting a new and startling picture of how cancer develops .
senseval2.d001.s002: An emerging understanding of the genes is expected to produce an array of new strategies for future cancer treatment and prevention .
senseval2.d001.s004: Already , scientists are developing tests based on the newly identified genes that , for the first time , can predict whether an otherwise healthy individual is likely to get cancer .
senseval2.d001.s005: `` It 's a super-exciting set of discoveries , `` says Bert Vogelstein , a Johns Hopkins University researcher who has just found a gene pivotal to the triggering of colon cancer .
senseval2.d001.s006: `` Only a decade ago cancer was a black box about which we knew nothing at the molecular level .
senseval2.d001.s007: Today , we know that the accumulation of several of these altered genes can initiate a cancer and , then , propel it into a deadly state . ``
senseval2.d001.s008: Scientists call the new class of genes tumor-suppressors , or simply anti-cancer genes .
senseval2.d001.s009: When functioning normally , they make proteins that hold a cell 's growth in check .
senseval2.d001.s010: But if the genes are damaged -- perhaps by radiation , a chemical or through a chance accident in cell division -- their growth-suppressing proteins no longer work , and cells normally under control turn malignant .
senseval2.d001.s011: The newly identified genes differ from a family of genes discovered in the early 1980s called oncogenes .
senseval2.d001.s012: Oncogenes must be present for a cell to become malignant , but researchers have found them in normal as well as in cancerous cells , suggesting that oncogenes do n't cause cancer by themselves .
senseval2.d001.s013: In recent months , researchers have come to believe the two types of cancer genes work in concert : An oncogene may turn proliferating cells malignant only after the tumor-suppressor gene has been damaged .
senseval2.d001.s014: Like all genes , tumor-suppressor genes are inherited in two copies , one from each parent .
senseval2.d001.s015: Either copy can make the proteins needed to control cell growth , so for cancer to arise , both copies must be impaired .
senseval2.d001.s016: A person who is born with one defective copy of a suppressor gene , or in whom one copy is damaged early in life , is especially prone to cancer because he need only lose the other copy for a cancer to develop .
senseval2.d001.s017: Emerging genetic tests will be able to spot such cancer-susceptible individuals , ushering in what some scientists believe is a new age of predictive cancer diagnosis .
senseval2.d001.s018: Bill and Bonnie Quinlan are among the first beneficiaries of the new findings .
senseval2.d001.s019: The Dedham , Mass. , couple knew even before Bonnie became pregnant in 1987 that any child of theirs had a 50 % chance of being at risk for retinoblastoma , an eye cancer that occurs about once every 20,000 births .
senseval2.d001.s020: Mr. Quinlan , 30 years old , knew he carried a damaged gene , having lost an eye to the rare tumor when he was only two months old -- after his mother had suffered the same fate when she was a baby .
senseval2.d001.s021: Because of the isolation of the retinoblastoma tumor-suppressor gene , it became possible last January to find out what threat the Quinlan baby faced .
senseval2.d001.s022: A test using new `` genetic probes `` showed that little Will Quinlan had not inherited a damaged retinoblastoma supressor gene and , therefore , faced no more risk than other children of developing the rare cancer .
senseval2.d001.s023: `` It made our New Year , `` says Mr. Quinlan .
senseval2.d001.s024: This test was the first to predict reliably whether an individual could expect to develop cancer .
senseval2.d001.s025: Equally important , the initial discovery of the gene that controls retinal cell growth , made by a Boston doctor named Thaddeus Dryja , has opened a field of cancer study , which in recent months has exploded .
senseval2.d001.s026: `` It turns out that studying a tragic but uncommon tumor made possible some fundamental insights about the most basic workings of cancer , `` says Samuel Broder , director of the National Cancer Institute .
senseval2.d001.s027: `` All this may not be obvious to the public , which is concerned about advances in treatment , but I am convinced this basic research will begin showing results there soon . ``
senseval2.d001.s028: To date , scientists have fingered two of these cancer-suppressors .
senseval2.d001.s029: Dr. Dryja made his retinoblastoma discovery in 1986 .
senseval2.d001.s030: Then last spring , researchers reported finding a gene called p53 which , if impaired , turns healthy colon cells cancerous .
senseval2.d001.s031: Soon after that report , two other research teams uncovered evidence that the same damaged p53 gene is present in tissue from lung and breast cancers .
senseval2.d001.s032: Colon , lung and breast cancers are the most common and lethal forms of the disease , collectively killing almost 200,000 Americans a year .
senseval2.d001.s033: Right now about a dozen laboratories , in the U.S. , Canada and Britain , are racing to unmask other suspected tumor-suppressing genes .
senseval2.d001.s035: Researchers say the inactivation of tumor-suppressor genes , alone or in combination , appears crucial to the development of such scourges as cancer of the brain , the skin , kidney , prostate , and cervix .
senseval2.d001.s036: There is evidence that if people inherit defective versions of these genes , they are especially prone to cancer , perhaps explaining , finally , why some cancers seem to haunt certain families .
senseval2.d001.s037: The story of tumor-suppressor genes goes back to the 1970s , when a pediatrician named Alfred G. Knudson Jr. proposed that retinoblastoma stemmed from two separate genetic defects .
senseval2.d001.s038: He theorized that in the eye cancer , an infant inherited a damaged copy of a gene from one parent and a normal copy from the other .
senseval2.d001.s039: The tumor , he suggested , developed when the second , normal copy also was damaged .
senseval2.d001.s040: But there was no way to prove Dr. Knudson 's `` two-hit `` theory .
senseval2.d001.s041: Back then , scientists had no way of ferreting out specific genes , but under a microscope they could see the 23 pairs of chromosomes in the cells that contain the genes .
senseval2.d001.s042: Occasionally , gross chromosome damage was visible .
senseval2.d001.s043: Dr. Knudson found that some children with the eye cancer had inherited a damaged copy of chromosome No. 13 from a parent who had had the disease .
senseval2.d001.s044: Under a microscope he could actually see that a bit of chromosome 13 was missing .
senseval2.d001.s045: He assumed the missing piece contained a gene or genes whose loss had a critical role in setting off the cancer .
senseval2.d001.s046: But he did not know which gene or genes had disappeared .
senseval2.d001.s047: Then , a scientific team led by molecular geneticist Webster Cavenee , then at the University of Utah , found the answer .
senseval2.d001.s048: The team used a battery of the newly developed `` gene probes , `` snippets of genetic material that can track a gene 's presence in a cell .
senseval2.d001.s049: By analyzing cells extracted from eye tumors , they found defects in the second copy of chromosome 13 in the exact area as in the first copy of the chromosome .
senseval2.d001.s051: It was the first time anyone had showed that the loss of both copies of the same gene could lead to the eruption of a cancer .
senseval2.d001.s052: `` It was extraordinarily satisfying , `` says Dr. Knudson , now at Fox Chase Cancer Research Center in Philadelphia .
senseval2.d001.s053: `` I was convinced that what was true of retinoblastoma would be true for all cancers . ``
senseval2.d001.s055: But in Baltimore , Dr. Vogelstein , a young molecular biologist at Johns Hopkins Medical School , believed Dr. Knudson was right , and set out to repeat the Cavenee experiment in cells from other cancers .
senseval2.d001.s056: His was one of two research teams in 1984 to report dual chromosome losses for a rare childhood cancer of the kidney called Wilm 's tumor .
senseval2.d001.s057: Dr. Vogelstein next turned his attention colon cancer , the second biggest cancer killer in the U.S. after lung cancer .
senseval2.d001.s058: He believed colon cancer might also arise from multiple `` hits `` on cancer suppressor genes , because it often seems to develop in stages .
senseval2.d001.s059: It often is preceded by the development of polyps in the bowel , which in some cases become increasingly malignant in identifiable stages -- progressing from less severe to deadly -- as though a cascade of genetic damage might be occurring .
senseval2.d001.s060: Dr. Vogelstein and a doctoral student , Eric Fearon , began months of tedious and often frustrating probing of the chromosomes searching for signs of genetic damage .
senseval2.d001.s061: They began uncovering a confusing variety of genetic deletions , some existing only in benign polyps , others in malignant cells and many in both polyps and malignant cells .
senseval2.d001.s062: Gradually , a coherent picture of cancer development emerged .
senseval2.d001.s063: If both copies of a certain gene were knocked out , benign polyps would develop .
senseval2.d001.s064: If both copies of a second gene were then deleted , the polyps would progress to malignancy .
senseval2.d001.s065: It was clear that more than one gene had to be damaged for colon cancer to develop .
senseval2.d001.s066: Their report galvanized other molecular biologists .
senseval2.d001.s067: `` It was the confirming evidence we all needed that gene losses were critical to the development of a common tumor , `` says Ray White at Howard Hughes Medical Institute in Salt Lake City .
senseval2.d001.s068: But Dr. Vogelstein had yet to nail the identity of the gene that , if damaged , flipped a colon cell into full-blown malignancy .
senseval2.d001.s070: For months the Johns Hopkins researchers , using gene probes , experimentally crawled down the length of chromosome 17 , looking for the smallest common bit of genetic material lost in all tumor cells .
senseval2.d001.s071: Such a piece of DNA would probably constitute a gene .
senseval2.d001.s072: When they found it last winter , Dr. Vogelstein was dubious that the search was over .
senseval2.d001.s073: His doubts stemmed from the fact that several years earlier a Princeton University researcher , Arnold Levine , had found in experiments with mice that a gene called p53 could transform normal cells into cancerous ones .
senseval2.d001.s074: The deletion Dr. Vogelstein found was in exactly the same spot as p53 .
senseval2.d001.s075: But Mr. Levine had said the p53 gene caused cancer by promoting growth , whereas the Johns Hopkins scientists were looking for a gene that suppressed growth .
senseval2.d001.s076: Despite that , when the Johns Hopkins scientists compared the gene they had found in the human cancer cells with the Mr. Levine 's p53 gene they found the two were identical ; it turned out that in Mr. Levine 's cancer studies , he had unknowingly been observing a damaged form of p53 -- a cancer-suppressing gene .
senseval2.d001.s077: The discovery `` suddenly puts an obscure gene right in the cockpit of cancer formation , `` says Robert Weinberg , a leader in cancer-gene research at Whitehead Institute in Cambridge , Mass .
senseval2.d001.s078: Evidence now is emerging that the p53 suppressor gene is involved in other cancers , too .
senseval2.d001.s079: Researchers in Edinburgh , Scotland , have found that in 23 of 38 breast tumors , one copy of chromosome 17 was mutated at the spot where gene p53 lies .
senseval2.d001.s080: The scientists say that since breast cancer often strikes multiple members of certain families , the gene , when inherited in a damaged form , may predispose women to the cancer .
senseval2.d001.s081: The p53 gene has just been implicated in lung cancer .
senseval2.d001.s082: In a report out last week , John Minna and colleagues at the National Cancer Institute say that about half the cells taken from lung cancer tissue they tested are missing this gene .
senseval2.d001.s083: There also are reports from several labs , as yet unpublished , of missing p53 genes in tissue taken from kidney , brain and skin cancers .
senseval2.d001.s084: At the same time , the Johns Hopkins team and others are rushing to pinpoint other tumor-suppressor genes .
senseval2.d001.s085: Dr. Vogelstein hopes soon to isolate one on chromosome 18 , also involved in colon cancer .
senseval2.d001.s086: Ray White in Utah and Walter Bodmer , a researcher in Great Britain , are close to finding another gene involved with some types of colon cancer , thought to be on chromosome 5 .
senseval2.d001.s087: Dr. Minna believes people who inherit a defective gene somewhere on one of their two copies of chromosome 3 are especially prone to lung cancer .
senseval2.d001.s088: Recently , he and others reported that the retinoblastoma suppressor gene may also be involved in some lung cancers , as well as several other more common cancers , too .
senseval2.d001.s089: Where these discoveries will lead , scientists can only speculate .
senseval2.d001.s090: Already two major pharmaceutical companies , the Squibb unit of Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. and Hoffmann-La Roche Inc. , are collaborating with gene hunters to turn the anticipated cascade of discoveries into predictive tests and , maybe , new therapies .
senseval2.d001.s091: Some researchers say new cancer drugs to slow or reverse tumor growth may be based on the suppressor proteins normally produced by the genes .
senseval2.d001.s092: The idea would be to administer to patients the growth-controlling proteins made by healthy versions of the damaged genes .
senseval2.d001.s093: It may even be possible to replace defective genes with healthy versions , though no one has come close to doing that so far .
senseval2.d001.s094: In any case , says Dr. Minna of the National Cancer Institute , `` We 're witnessing the discovery of one of the most important steps in the genesis of cancer .
senseval2.d002.s000: Why ca not we teach our children to read , write and reckon ?
senseval2.d002.s001: It 's not that we do not know how to , because we do .
senseval2.d002.s002: It 's that we do not want to .
senseval2.d002.s003: And the reason we do not want to is that effective education would require us to relinquish some cherished metaphysical beliefs about human nature in general and the human nature of young people in particular , well as to violate some cherished vested interests .
senseval2.d002.s004: These beliefs so dominate our educational establishment , our media , our politicians , and even our parents that it seems almost blasphemous to challenge them .
senseval2.d002.s006: If I were to ask a sample of American parents , `` Do you wish the elementary schools to encourage creativity in your children ? `` the near-unanimous answer would be , `` Yes , of course . ``
senseval2.d002.s007: But what do we mean , specifically , by `` creativity `` ?
senseval2.d002.s009: In practice , it ends up being equated with a `` self-expression `` that encourages the youngsters ' `` self-esteem . ``
senseval2.d002.s010: The result is a generation of young people whose ignorance and intellectual incompetence is matched only by their good opinion of themselves .
senseval2.d002.s011: The whole notion of `` creativity `` in education was ( and is ) part and parcel of a romantic rebellion against disciplined instruction , which was ( and is ) regarded as `` authoritarian , `` a repression and frustration of the latent talents and the wonderful , if as yet undefined , potentialities inherent in the souls of all our children .
senseval2.d002.s012: It is not surprising that parents find this romantic extravagance so attractive .
senseval2.d002.s013: Fortunately , these same parents do want their children to get a decent education as traditionally understood , and they have enough common sense to know what that demands .
senseval2.d002.s014: Their commitment to `` creativity `` can not survive adolescent illiteracy .
senseval2.d002.s015: American education 's future will be determined by the degree to which we -- all of us -- allow this common sense to prevail over the illusions that we also share .
senseval2.d002.s016: The education establishment will fight against common sense every inch of the way .
senseval2.d002.s017: The reasons are complex , but one simple reason ought not to be underestimated .
senseval2.d002.s018: `` Progressive education `` ( as it was once called ) is far more interesting and agreeable to teachers than is disciplined instruction .
senseval2.d002.s019: It is nice for teachers to think they are engaged in `` personality development `` and even nicer to minimize those irksome tests with often disappointing results .
senseval2.d002.s020: It also provides teachers with a superior self-definition as a `` profession , `` since they will have passed courses in educational psychology and educational philosophy .
senseval2.d002.s021: I myself took such courses in college , thinking I might end up a schoolteacher .
senseval2.d002.s022: They could all fairly be described as `` pap `` courses .
senseval2.d002.s023: But it is unfair to dump on teachers , as distinct from the educational establishment .
senseval2.d002.s024: I know many schoolteachers and , on the whole , they are seriously committed to conscientious teaching .
senseval2.d002.s025: They may not be among the `` best and brightest `` of their generation -- there are very few such people , by definition .
senseval2.d002.s026: But they need not be to do their jobs well .
senseval2.d002.s027: Yes , we all can remember one or two truly inspiring teachers from our school days .
senseval2.d002.s028: But our education proceeded at the hands of those others , who were merely competent and conscientious .
senseval2.d002.s029: In this sense , a teacher can be compared to one 's family doctor .
senseval2.d002.s030: If he were brilliant , he probably would not be a family doctor in the first place .
senseval2.d002.s031: If he is competent and conscientious , he serves us well .
senseval2.d002.s032: Our teachers are not an important factor in our educational crisis .
senseval2.d002.s033: Whether they are or are not underpaid is a problem of equity ; it is not an educational problem .
senseval2.d002.s034: It is silly libel on our teachers to think they would educate our children better if only they got a few thousand dollars a year more .
senseval2.d002.s035: It is the kind of libel the teachers ' unions do not mind spreading , for their own narrow purposes .
senseval2.d002.s036: It is also the kind of libel politicians find useful , since it helps them strike a friendly posture on behalf of an important constituency .
senseval2.d002.s037: But there is not one shred of evidence that , other things being equal , salary differentials result in educational differentials .
senseval2.d002.s038: If there were such evidence , you can be sure you would have heard of it .
senseval2.d002.s039: If we wish to be serious about American education , we know exactly what to do -- and , just as important , what not to do .
senseval2.d002.s040: There are many successful schools scattered throughout this nation , some of them in the poorest of ghettos , and they are all sending us the same message .
senseval2.d002.s041: Conversely , there are the majority of unsuccessful schools , and we know which efforts at educational reform are doomed beforehand .
senseval2.d002.s042: We really do know all we need to know , if only we could assimilate this knowledge into our thinking .
senseval2.d002.s043: In this respect , it would be helpful if our political leaders were mute , rather than eloquently `` concerned . ``
senseval2.d002.s044: They are inevitably inclined to echo the conventional pap , since this is the least controversial option that is open to them .
senseval2.d002.s045: Thus at the recent governors ' conference on education , Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas announced that `` this country needs a comprehensive child-development policy for children under five . ``
senseval2.d002.s046: A comprehensive development policy for governors over 30 would seem to be a more pressing need .
senseval2.d002.s047: What Gov. Clinton is advocating , in effect , is extending the educational system down to the pre-kindergarten years .
senseval2.d002.s048: Whether desirable or not , this is a child-care program , not an educational program .
senseval2.d002.s049: We know that very early exposure to schooling improves performance in the first grade , but afterward the difference is quickly washed away .
senseval2.d002.s050: Let us sum up what we do know about education and about those education reforms that do work and do not work : -- `` Parental involvement `` is a bad idea .
senseval2.d002.s051: Parents are too likely to blame schools for the educational limitations of their children .
senseval2.d002.s052: Parents should be involved with their children 's education at home , not in school .
senseval2.d002.s053: They should see to it that their kids do not play truant ; they should make certain that the children spend enough time doing homework ; they should scrutinize the report card .
senseval2.d002.s054: If parents are dissatisfied with a school , they should have the option of switching to another .

senseval3.d001.s000: Tuesday 's rout of a GOP congressional hopeful in a Mississippi district that has n't backed a Democratic presidential candidate since Adlai Stevenson is another reminder that , at least at the federal level , political `` ticket splitting `` has been on the rise over the past half century .
senseval3.d001.s001: In only one presidential election year prior to 1948 did more than 20 % of the nation 's congressional districts choose a different party 's candidate for the White House than for the House of Representatives .
senseval3.d001.s002: Now that percentage routinely equals a third and twice has been above 40 % .
senseval3.d001.s003: As we know , voters tend to favor Republicans more in races for president than in those for Congress .
senseval3.d001.s004: In every presidential election over the past half century , except for the Goldwater presidential candidacy , the GOP has captured a greater percentage of the major - party popular vote for president than it has of congressional seats or the popular vote for Congress .
senseval3.d001.s005: Prior to 1932 , the pattern was nearly the opposite .
senseval3.d001.s006: What accounts for the results of recent decades ?
senseval3.d001.s007: A simple economic theory may provide at least a partial explanation for the split personality displayed by Americans in the voting booth .
senseval3.d001.s008: The theory relies on three assumptions :
senseval3.d001.s009: 1 -RRB- Voters can `` buy `` one of two brands when they select their political agents -- a Republican brand that believes in the minimalist state and in the virtues of private markets over the vices of public action , and a Democratic brand that believes in big government and in public intervention to remedy the excesses attendant to the pursuit of private interest .
senseval3.d001.s010: 2 -RRB- Congressional representatives have two basic responsibilities while voting in office -- dealing with national issues -LRB- programmatic actions such as casting roll call votes on legislation that imposes costs and/or confers benefits on the population at large -RRB- and attending to local issues -LRB- constituency service and pork barrel -RRB- .
senseval3.d001.s011: 3 -RRB- Republican congressional representatives , because of their belief in a minimalist state , are less willing to engage in local benefit-seeking than are Democratic members of Congress .
senseval3.d001.s012: If these assumptions hold , voters in races for Congress face what in economic theory is called a prisoner 's dilemma and have an incentive , at the margin , to lean Democratic .
senseval3.d001.s013: If they put a Republican into office , not only will they acquire less in terms of local benefits but their selected legislator will be relatively powerless to prevent other legislators from `` bringing home the bacon `` to their respective constituencies .
senseval3.d001.s014: Each legislator , after all , is only one out of 535 when it comes to national policy making .
senseval3.d001.s015: In races for the White House , a voter 's incentive , at the margin , is to lean Republican .
senseval3.d001.s016: Although a GOP president may limit local benefits to the voter 's particular district/state , such a president is also likely to be more effective at preventing other districts/states and their legislators from bringing home the local benefits .
senseval3.d001.s017: The individual voter 's standing consequently will be enhanced through lower taxes .
senseval3.d001.s018: While this theory is exceedingly simple , it appears to explain several things .
senseval3.d001.s019: First , why ticket splitting has increased and taken the peculiar pattern that it has over the past half century : Prior to the election of Franklin Roosevelt as president and the advent of the New Deal , government occupied a much smaller role in society and the prisoner 's dilemma problem confronting voters in races for Congress was considerably less severe .
senseval3.d001.s020: Second , it explains why voters hold Congress in disdain but generally love their own congressional representatives : Any individual legislator 's constituents appreciate the specific benefits that the legislator wins for them but not the overall cost associated with every other legislator doing likewise for his own constituency .
senseval3.d001.s021: Third , the theory suggests why legislators who pay too much attention to national policy making relative to local benefit-seeking have lower security in office .
senseval3.d001.s022: For example , first-term members of the House , once the most vulnerable of incumbents , have become virtually immune to defeat .
senseval3.d001.s023: The one exception to this recent trend was the defeat of 13 of the 52 freshman Republicans brought into office in 1980 by the Reagan revolution and running for re-election in 1982 .
senseval3.d001.s024: Because these freshmen placed far more emphasis on their partisan role -- spreading the Reagan revolution -- in national policy making , they were more vulnerable to defeat .
senseval3.d001.s025: Fourth , the theory indicates why the Republican Party may have a difficult time attracting viable candidates for congressional office .
senseval3.d001.s026: Potential candidates may be discouraged from running less by the congressional salary than by the prospect of defeat at the hands of a Democratic opponent .
senseval3.d001.s027: To the extent that potential Republican candidates and their financial backers realize that the congressional prisoner 's dilemma game works to their disadvantage , the Republican Party will be hindered in its attempts to field a competitive slate of congressional candidates .
senseval3.d001.s028: Fifth , the theory may provide at least a partial reason for why ticket splitting has been particularly pronounced in the South .
senseval3.d001.s029: To the extent that Democratic legislators from the South have held a disproportionate share of power in Congress since 1932 and have been able to translate such clout into relatively more local benefits for their respective constituencies , voters in the South have had an especially strong incentive to keep such Democrats in office .
senseval3.d001.s030: Finally , the theory suggests why Republicans generally have fared better in Senate races than in campaigns for the House .
senseval3.d001.s031: Since local benefit-seeking matters more and national policy making matters less in the lower chamber of Congress , this is precisely the pattern one would expect if Republicans are less willing to engage in local benefit-seeking than their Democratic counterparts .
senseval3.d001.s032: Is there any empirical support for this theory ?
senseval3.d001.s033: Three pieces of evidence corroborate the key assumption that Democratic legislators are more willing to engage in local benefit-seeking than their Republican colleagues .
senseval3.d001.s034: First , economists James Bennett and Thomas DiLorenzo find that GOP senators turn back roughly 10 % more of their allocated personal staff budgets than Democrats do .
senseval3.d001.s035: To the extent that the primary duty of personal staff involves local benefit-seeking , this indicates that political philosophy leads congressional Republicans to pay less attention to narrow constituent concerns .
senseval3.d001.s036: Second , if the key assumption is valid , Democrats should have lower attendance rates on roll-call votes than Republicans do to the extent that such votes reflect national policy making and that participating in such votes takes away from the time a legislator could otherwise devote to local benefit-seeking .
senseval3.d001.s037: This is indeed what the data indicate , particularly in the case of the House .
senseval3.d001.s038: The Democratic House attendance rate has not exceeded the Republican House attendance rate since 1959 .
senseval3.d001.s039: Finally , as shown in the table , Democrats allocate a higher proportion of their personal staffs to district offices -- where local benefit-seeking duties matter more and national policy making activities matter less relative to Washington offices .
senseval3.d001.s040: An examination of changes in personal staffing decisions in the Senate between 1986 and 1987 -LRB- when control of that body changed party hands -RRB- , moreover , reveals that the personal staffing differences noted in the table can not be attributed to the disproportionate control Democrats exercise , due to their majority-party status , over other resources such as committee staff .
senseval3.d001.s041: An additional piece of evidence from the Senate : Holding other factors constant , such as incumbency advantages and regional factors , the difference between popular votes for Republican presidential and senatorial candidates in states conducting a Senate election turns out to be a positive function of how onerous the federal government 's tax burden is per state -LRB- a progressive tax rate hits higher - income states harder -RRB- .
senseval3.d001.s042: Put more simply , GOP candidates for president are looked on more kindly by voters than Republican candidates for the Senate when the prisoner 's dilemma is more severe .
senseval3.d001.s043: Moreover , ticket splitting appears to take the same peculiar pattern at the state government level as it does at the federal level .
senseval3.d001.s044: State government is more typically split along Republican-governor / Democratic-legislature lines than the reverse .
senseval3.d001.s045: A cross-state econometric investigation , furthermore , reveals that , holding other factors constant , the difference between a state 's major - party vote going to the Republican gubernatorial candidate and the Republican share of the lower state house is a positive function of the state tax rate .
senseval3.d001.s046: In sum , at both the federal and state government levels at least part of the seemingly irrational behavior voters display in the voting booth may have an exceedingly rational explanation .

semeval2010.d001.s001: 5 What are the five lessons learnt from the evaluation and what do these mean for the nature conservation policy ?
semeval2010.d001.s002: a. Increasing the area of National Ecological Network further .
semeval2010.d001.s003: In order to realise the National Ecological Network by 2018 and to enhance the coherence within the National Ecological Network great efforts have to be made towards realising the surface area of the National Ecological Network ( some 730,000 ha of land by 2018 ).
semeval2010.d001.s004: In the years to come the strategy is aimed at further increasing the area of the National Ecological Network .
semeval2010.d001.s005: b. Improving the quality of the National Ecological Network .
semeval2010.d001.s006: The number of species is still declining , although the pace at which this is happening has slowed down .
semeval2010.d001.s007: An impulse should be given with respect to the environmental conditions and the spatial coherence between the areas .
semeval2010.d001.s008: Acidification and over-fertilisation in particular can be tackled more vigorously through instruments specifically designed for certain areas ( for example , expanding the nature areas and developing buffer zones around them ).
semeval2010.d001.s009: The efforts against water depletion need to be intensified and require an a large-scale approach aimed at the entire water catchment , not just at individual sites .
semeval2010.d001.s010: The benefits for the nature in the bordered National Ecological Network can be increased provided that specific measures are taken in each of the areas , while taking the entire water catchment into account .
semeval2010.d001.s012: In addition to the government acquiring land for the organisations that manage large areas , the National Ecological Network can in part be realized by involving farmers and other private individuals ( for example country estate owners ) in the development and management of natural sites .
semeval2010.d001.s013: The farmer remains owner of the land but in addition to being a farmer he would then be a manager of the natural site as well .
semeval2010.d001.s014: The government provides the farmer with a subsidy for this management function .
semeval2010.d001.s015: In addition , over the last few years the government has reserved extra financial resources for land acquisition because of the increased land prices .
semeval2010.d001.s016: The present cabinet has also made more funds available in order to be able to complete the National Ecological Network by 2018 .
semeval2010.d001.s017: These extra funds are intended for land acquisition , design , management , defragmentation measures and for measures to combat water depletion in the nature areas .
semeval2010.d001.s018: d. Creating more connections as a solution for the problem of too little coherence .
semeval2010.d001.s019: The construction of robust connections i.e.
semeval2010.d001.s020: covering a large surface area ( often both in terms of width and length ) is receiving priority over the smaller connections .
semeval2010.d001.s021: In 2000 the policy document '' Nature for People , People for Nature '' was issued in which the policy was modified according to the evaluation .
semeval2010.d001.s022: The ambition of this policy document is to proceed more vigorously with the realisation of the National Ecological Network .
semeval2010.d001.s023: The spatial coherence - and therefore the functioning - of the National Ecological Network is enhanced by constructing boundaries in a smarter way and by realising green connections between and within nature areas .
semeval2010.d001.s024: That is why on the one hand extra efforts are being made to create '' green-blue pathways '' in the man-made landscape .
semeval2010.d001.s025: This helps establish a coherent network of lines and flat elements in the landscape .
semeval2010.d001.s026: On the other hand efforts are being made towards realising a number of robust connections between larger ecological core areas .
semeval2010.d001.s027: The design phase is a very important stage in this process in order to convert the objectives ( and the wishes ) into the desired result .
semeval2010.d001.s028: e. Creating robust connections has priority .
semeval2010.d001.s029: Robust connections can either be green ( terrestrial ) or blue ( aquatic ).
semeval2010.d001.s030: They connect nature areas that are spatially separated from one another and increase the spatial coherence at national level .
semeval2010.d001.s031: This involves connections between comparable nature areas ( ecosystems such as marshes , woodland and heath ) or very dissimilar areas , for example transition areas from wet to dry or from oligotrophic to eutrophic .
semeval2010.d001.s032: Examples of this are river valleys on sandy soil and the transition areas from dunes to peat marshes .
semeval2010.d001.s033: Robust connections ensure that new nature areas are accessible and that areas where the species die out can be colonised once more .
semeval2010.d001.s034: The connections also enable species to move to other regions ( for example , in the event of climate change or disasters ).
semeval2010.d001.s035: The connections obtain their robustness through their area and form .
semeval2010.d001.s036: As the robust connections have to accommodate a very wide range of species ( for example red deer , adders , otters and butterflies , but also birds ) they should consist of wide zones with a mosaic of various types of habitats .
semeval2010.d001.s037: To an increasing extent they have to form more or less complete ecosystems in themselves .
semeval2010.d001.s038: The robust connections will cover a total area of 27,000 ha ( see figure on the left ).
semeval2010.d001.s039: The form and the size of the individual robust connections will vary from one another .
semeval2010.d001.s040: Depending on the situation , a '' corridor '' or '' stepping stone '' may be required , or a combination of the two .
semeval2010.d001.s042: the connections consist of smaller links and larger junctions ( living habitats ).
semeval2010.d001.s043: For other species these links can also function as habitats .
semeval2010.d001.s044: Robust connections are part of the National Ecological Network and function as part of nature .
semeval2010.d001.s045: They form a condition for the preservation of the biodiversity at national , regional and local levels .
semeval2010.d001.s046: But they can also provide space for recreation , water management or water extraction .
semeval2010.d001.s047: In addition they improve the landscape and the cultural-historical identity of an area .
semeval2010.d001.s048: In 2003 governmental agreements were made between the Ministry of Agriculture , Nature Management and Fisheries and the provinces regarding the general locations , the area required , the pace of the realisation and the ecological ambitions of the 12 robust connections .
semeval2010.d001.s049: The setting of accurate boundaries and the delivery of robust connections is a task of the provinces .
semeval2010.d001.s050: In 2018 the robust connections , along with the rest of the National Ecological Network , should be complete .
semeval2010.d001.s051: The defragmentation of all state infrastructures within the robust connections would then also be accomplished .

semeval2010.d001.s066: These all provide new opportunities to nature .

semeval2010.d002.s002: The Humber Estuary is the largest macro-tidal estuary on the British North Sea coast .
semeval2010.d002.s003: It drains a catchment of some 24,240 square kilometres and is the site of the largest single input of freshwater from Britain into the North Sea .
semeval2010.d002.s004: It has the second-highest tidal range in Britain ( max 7.4 m ) and approximately one-third of the estuary is exposed as mud or sand flats at low tide .
semeval2010.d002.s005: The inner estuary supports extensive areas of reedbed with areas of mature and developing saltmarsh backed in places by limited areas of grazing marsh in the middle and outer estuary .
semeval2010.d002.s006: On the north Lincolnshire coast the saltmarsh is backed by low sand dunes with marshy slacks and brackish pools .
semeval2010.d002.s007: The Estuary regularly supports internationally important numbers of waterfowl in winter and nationally important breeding populations in summer .
semeval2010.d002.s008: 14. Justification for the application of each Criterion listed in 13 above :
semeval2010.d002.s010: The site is a representative example of a near-natural estuary with the following component habitats :
semeval2010.d002.s011: dune systems and humid dune slacks , estuarine waters , intertidal mud and sand flats , saltmarshes , and coastal brackish / saline lagoons .
semeval2010.d002.s012: It is a large macro-tidal coastal plain estuary with high suspended sediment loads , which feed a dynamic and rapidly changing system of accreting and eroding intertidal and subtidal mudflats , sandflats , saltmarsh and reedbeds .
semeval2010.d002.s013: Examples of both strandline , foredune , mobile , semi-fixed dunes , fixed dunes and dune grassland occur on both banks of the estuary and along the coast .
semeval2010.d002.s014: The estuary supports a full range of saline conditions from the open coast to the limit of saline intrusion on the tidal rivers of the Ouse and Trent .
semeval2010.d002.s015: Wave exposed sandy shores are found in the outer / open coast areas of the estuary .
semeval2010.d002.s016: These change to the more moderately exposed sandy shores and then to sheltered muddy shores within the main body of the estuary and up into the tidal rivers .
semeval2010.d002.s017: The lower saltmarsh of the Humber is dominated by common cordgrass Spartina anglica and annual glasswort Salicornia communities .
semeval2010.d002.s018: Low to mid marsh communities are mostly represented by sea Aster tripolium , common saltmarsh grass Puccinellia maritima and sea purslane Atriplex portulacoides communities .
semeval2010.d002.s019: The upper portion of the saltmarsh community is atypical , dominated by sea couch Elytrigia atherica ( Elymus pycnanthus ) saltmarsh community .
semeval2010.d002.s020: In the upper reaches of the estuary , the tidal marsh community is dominated by the common reed Phragmites australis fen and sea club rush Bolboschoenus maritimus swamp with the couch grass Elytrigia repens ( Elymus repens ) saltmarsh community .
semeval2010.d002.s021: Within the Humber Estuary Ramsar site there are good examples of four of the five physiographic types of saline lagoon .
semeval2010.d002.s023: The Humber Estuary Ramsar site supports a breeding colony of gray seals Halichoerus grypus at Donna Nook .
semeval2010.d002.s024: It is the second largest gray seal colony in England and the furthest south regular breeding site on the east coast .
semeval2010.d002.s025: The dune slacks at Saltfleetby-Theddlethorpe on the southern extremity of the Ramsar site are the most north-easterly breeding site in Great Britain of the natterjack toad Bufo calamita .
semeval2010.d002.s027: General description of the Physical Features :
semeval2010.d002.s028: The Humber estuary is approximately 70 km long from the limit of saline intrusion on the River Ouse at Boothferry to the estuary mouth at Spurn Head , where it enters the North Sea .
semeval2010.d002.s029: The area of the estuary is approx. 365 km2 , and it has a width of 6.6 km at the mouth .
semeval2010.d002.s030: The Humber is a macro-tidal estuary with a tidal range of 7.4 m , the second-largest range in the UK and comparable to other macro-tidal estuaries worldwide .
semeval2010.d002.s031: It is a shallow and well mixed estuary , with an average depth of 6.5m rising to 13.2 m at the mouth .
semeval2010.d002.s032: The Humber is the second-largest coastal plain estuary in the UK , and the largest coastal plain estuary on the east coast of Britain .
semeval2010.d002.s033: Suspended sediment concentrations are high , and are derived from a variety of sources , including marine sediments and eroding boulder clay along the Holderness coast .
semeval2010.d002.s034: This is the northernmost of the English east coast estuaries whose structure and function is intimately linked with soft eroding shorelines .
semeval2010.d002.s035: Upstream from the Humber Bridge , the navigation channel undergoes major shifts from north to south banks .
semeval2010.d002.s036: This section of the estuary is noteworthy for extensive mud and sand bars , which in places form semi-permanent islands .
semeval2010.d002.s037: The estuary covers the full salinity range from fully marine at the mouth of the estuary ( Spurn Head ) to the limit of saline intrusion on the Rivers Ouse and Trent .
semeval2010.d002.s038: A salinity gradient from north to south bank is observed in the outer estuary , due to the incoming tide flowing along the north bank , while the fresh water keeps to the south bank as it discharges to the sea .
semeval2010.d002.s039: As salinity declines upstream , reedbeds and brackish saltmarsh communities fringe the estuary .
semeval2010.d002.s040: 17. Physical features of the catchment area :
semeval2010.d002.s041: The Humber catchment covers an area of ca .
semeval2010.d002.s042: 24,240 km2 , more than 20% of the land area of England .
semeval2010.d002.s043: Average annual precipitation in the upland areas of the catchment is as much as 1000 mm .
semeval2010.d002.s044: Average freshwater flow into the Humber estuary from the rivers is 250 m3s-1 , ranging from 60 m3s-1 in drier periods to 450 m3s-1 in wet periods .
semeval2010.d002.s045: Peak flows of up to 1500 m3s-1 have been recorded during floods .
semeval2010.d002.s046: The rivers Trent and Ouse , which provide the main fresh water flow into the Humber , drain large industrial and urban areas to the south and west ( River Trent ), and less densely populated agricultural areas to the north and west ( River Ouse ).
semeval2010.d002.s047: The Trent / Ouse confluence is known as Trent Falls .
semeval2010.d002.s048: On the north bank of the Humber estuary the principal river is the river Hull , which flows through the city of Kingston-upon-Hull , and has a tidal length of 32 km , up to the Hempholme Weir .
semeval2010.d002.s049: The Hull provides only about 1% of the freshwater input to the estuary .
semeval2010.d002.s050: On the south bank , the River Ancholme enters the Humber at South Ferriby , but the tide is excluded by a sluice and a tidal lock .
semeval2010.d002.s051: Altogether , the total tidal length of rivers and estuary is 313 km .
semeval2010.d002.s052: There are several major urban centres within the river catchments .
semeval2010.d002.s053: Nottingham , Leicester , and the West Midlands / Birmingham conurbation are drained by the Trent , the Leeds-Bradford area in West Yorkshire is drained by the Aire / Calder and the Sheffield / Rotherham / Doncaster area in South Yorkshire is drained by the Don .
semeval2010.d002.s054: There are also large rural regions , whose populations are currently experiencing high population growth , while the urban areas are showing a small decline .
semeval2010.d002.s055: The 1992 population for the Ouse catchment was 4.1 million , and for the Trent catchment was 7.1 million .
semeval2010.d002.s056: The population of Humberside , which comprises North and North-east Lincolnshire , the East Riding of Yorkshire , and Kingston-upon-Hull ( Hull ), was just under 0.9 million .
semeval2010.d002.s057: Land use around the estuary itself is 50-98% agricultural , within only two areas of high population / industry - the major conurbation around Kingston-upon-Hull ( Hull ) on the north bank , and several large industrial areas around Grimsby / Immingham / Cleesthorpes on the south bank .
semeval2010.d002.s058: The area around the Humber estuary is low-lying , and much land-claim of wetlands and supratidal zones , as well as parts of the intertidal zone , was carried out in the past two centuries .
semeval2010.d002.s059: The mid to outer estuary ( Humber Bridge to Spurn Point ) changed from a region of low water erosion in the 19th century to one of accretion in the 20th century , nonetheless a net loss of intertidal zone of some 3000 ha has taken place since the mid-19th century .
semeval2010.d002.s060: Around the estuary some 894 km2 of land are below the 5 m contour , protected by extensive coastal defences .
semeval2010.d002.s061: Most of the sediment entering the estuary comes from the North Sea , and a large part of it is believed to come from the continuing erosion of the Holderness Cliffs , which form the coastline to the north of the estuary mouth at Spurn Head .
semeval2010.d002.s065: Much of the intertidal area of the Humber Estuary consists of mudflats with fringing saltmarsh .
semeval2010.d002.s066: There are smaller areas of intertidal sand flats , and sand dunes .
semeval2010.d002.s067: The saltmarsh is both eroding and accreting ; although coastal squeeze is resulting in net losses , and cord grass Spartina anglica is a major colonising species .
semeval2010.d002.s068: In areas of reduced salinity such as the Upper Humber there are extensive areas of common reed Phragmites australis with some sea club-rush Bolboschoenus maritimus .
semeval2010.d002.s069: Mid-level saltmarsh tends to be much more floristically diverse , and in the higher level marsh with its dendritic network of drainage channels , salt pans and borrow pits grasses dominate with thrift Armeria maritima where the marsh is grazed by cattle and sheep .
semeval2010.d002.s070: Extensive areas of eelgrass Zostera marina and Z. nolti have been known to occur at Spurn Bight , although in recent years records are limited .

semeval2010.d003.s002: The Living Planet Index is a measure of the state of the world 's biodiversity based on trends from 1970 to 2003 in over 3 600 populations of more than 1 300 vertebrate species from around the world .
semeval2010.d003.s003: It is calculated as the average of three separate indices that measure trends in populations of 695 terrestrial species , 274 marine species , and 344 freshwater species .
semeval2010.d003.s004: The index shows an overall decline of around 30 per cent over the 33-year period , as do each of the terrestrial , marine , and freshwater indices individually .
semeval2010.d003.s005: The decline in the indices , and in particular the freshwater index , is less than in previous reports , because the indices have been aggregated in a different way , designed to reduce the degree of uncertainty around them ( see technical notes , page 37 ).
semeval2010.d003.s006: No attempt is made to select species on the basis of geography , ecology , or taxonomy , so the index dataset contains more population trends from wellresearched groups , especially birds , and well-studied regions , particularly Europe and North America .
semeval2010.d003.s007: In compensation , temperate and tropical regions are given equal weight ( with equal weight to each species in each region ) within the terrestrial and freshwater indices , and to ocean basins within the marine index ( see pages 6-11 ).
semeval2010.d003.s008: The map opposite shows the Earth 's surface divided into 14 terrestrial biomes , or habitat types , and eight biogeographic realms .
semeval2010.d003.s009: The biomes are based on habitat cover ( agricultural and urban land is classified according to potential vegetation type ) and realms are defined according to biological evolutionary history .
semeval2010.d003.s010: Although ecosystems within a single biome share the same ecological processes and vegetation types , their exact species composition varies depending on the realm in which they are found .
semeval2010.d003.s011: Patterns in freshwater biodiversity follow similar distinctions based on biogeographic realms , but marine realms are less well defined , partly because marine species tend to be distributed more widely across the world 's oceans .
semeval2010.d003.s014: The terrestrial species index shows a 31 per cent decline on average from 1970 to 2003 .
semeval2010.d003.s017: The marine species index shows an average decline of 27 per cent between 1970 and 2003 .
semeval2010.d003.s020: The freshwater species index declined by approximately 28 per cent between 1970 and 2003 .
semeval2010.d003.s022: Populations of terrestrial species declined by about 30 per cent on average between 1970 and 2003 .
semeval2010.d003.s023: This decline hides a marked difference in trends between temperate and tropical species .
semeval2010.d003.s024: Tropical species populations declined by around 55 per cent on average from 1970 to 2003 , while temperate species populations , which would have shown marked declines prior to 1970 , have shown little overall change since .
semeval2010.d003.s025: Figure 7 shows average trends in populations of 695 temperate and tropical terrestrial species ( of which 562 occur in temperate zones and 150 in tropical zones ), indexed to a value of one in 1970 .
semeval2010.d003.s026: The rapid rate of population decline in tropical species is mirrored by the loss of natural habitat to cropland or pasture in the tropics between 1950 and 1990 ( Figure 9 ), agricultural conversion being the main driver .
semeval2010.d003.s027: The tropical forests of Southeast Asia , part of the Indomalayan biogeographic realm , have seen the fastest conversion in the last two decades .
semeval2010.d003.s028: In temperate ecosystems , the conversion of natural habitat to farmland largely took place before 1950 , when populations of temperate species are likely to have declined , before stabilizing .
semeval2010.d003.s029: The biomes (see Map 1) with the fastest rate of conversion in the last half of the 20th century were tropical grasslands , flooded grasslands , and tropical dry forests ( Figure 8 ).
semeval2010.d003.s030: Temperate , tropical , and flooded grasslands , Mediterranean woodlands , temperate broadleaf forests , and tropical dry forests have all lost more than half of their estimated original habitat cover .
semeval2010.d003.s031: The biomes least transformed by agricultural conversion are boreal forests and tundra .

semeval2010.d003.s048: The marine environment , which covers almost 70 per cent of the Earth 's surface , includes some of the world 's most diverse and productive ecosystems , but these were adversely affected by human action over the last half of the 20th century .
semeval2010.d003.s049: The marine index is split by ocean basin .
semeval2010.d003.s050: The Pacific Ocean , the largest , covers more than a third of the planet 's surface .
semeval2010.d003.s051: The Atlantic Ocean includes the Arctic basin .

semeval2010.d003.s053: The Southern Ocean comprises the seas around Antarctica , its northern limit defined as the line of latitude 60 .
semeval2010.d003.s054: The marine index includes trends in 1 112 populations of 274 species between 1970 and 2003 , and shows a greater than 25 per cent decline on average across the four ocean basins .
semeval2010.d003.s055: Relatively stable trends are evident in the Pacific and in the Arctic / Atlantic Oceans , in comparison with dramatic declines in the Indian / Southeast Asian and Southern Oceans .
semeval2010.d003.s056: Overall increases in the populations of sea birds and some mammal species in the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans since 1970 , however , mask a decline in many fish species , especially those of economic importance such as cod and tuna , which are decreasing as a result of overfishing , as well as turtles and other species that are caught as by-catch .
semeval2010.d003.s057: There are comparatively few data from the Southern and Indian Oceans , so those indices end in 1997 and 2000 .
semeval2010.d003.s058: Mangroves - saltwater-tolerant , inter-tidal forests growing along tropical shorelines are among the most productive ecosystems on Earth and critical to the health of tropical marine ecosystems .
semeval2010.d003.s059: Mangroves provide nurseries for 85 per cent of commercial fish species in the tropics and are essential in maintaining fish stocks and hence food resources .
semeval2010.d003.s060: Mangroves are being degraded or destroyed at about twice the rate of tropical forests .
semeval2010.d003.s061: It is estimated that more than a third of the global area of mangrove forest was lost between 1990 and 2000 ( Figure 12 ).

semeval2010.d003.s070: More than a quarter of Asia 's mangrove cover was lost in the ten-year period preceding 2000 .
semeval2010.d003.s071: In South America , almost half was lost over the same period ( Mayaux et al ., 2005 ).

semeval2010.d003.s079: Species populations in both declined by about 30 per cent between 1970 and 2003 .
semeval2010.d003.s080: There is a difference in trends between freshwater birds , which appear to have been relatively stable , and other freshwater species , which have declined on average by about 50 per cent over the same period .

semeval2013.d000.s000: U.N. group drafts plan to reduce emissions
semeval2013.d000.s001: The U.N.-sponsored climate conference -- characterized so far by unruly posturing and mutual recriminations -- gained renewed focus Friday with the release of a document outlining ambitious greenhouse-gas reductions over the next 40 years , with industrialized nations shouldering most of the burden in the near term .
semeval2013.d000.s002: The text , which could provide the basis for a final political deal to regulate greenhouse gases , highlighted the remaining obstacles as much as it illuminated a path forward .
semeval2013.d000.s003: But it was seen as an important advance in a negotiation that is running out of time , with more than 100 world leaders arriving in Copenhagen next week .
semeval2013.d000.s004: Forged by a U.N. ad-hoc working group , the text is silent on how much money rich countries would give poor ones to cope with global warming over the short and long term .
semeval2013.d000.s005: And it provides a range of options for the key questions , including how developed and major emerging economies would cut their carbon output , and what would be the upper limit of global temperature rise that policymakers would be willing to tolerate .
semeval2013.d000.s006: It gives a lot of flexibility to the process , said John Coequyt , senior Washington representative for the Sierra Club .
semeval2013.d000.s007: Michael Zammit Cutajar , who drafted the six-page document , boiled down a 180-page negotiation text to focus on what the U.N. 's top climate official , Yvo de Boer , described as `` the big picture . ''
semeval2013.d000.s008: It shows the outlines for a possible deal , in which industrial nations would collectively cut their emissions by 2020 by 25 to 45 percent compared with 1990 levels , while major developing countries would reduce theirs during the same period by 15 to 30 percent .
semeval2013.d000.s009: Together , the countries would cut emissions between 50 and 95 percent by 2050 .
semeval2013.d000.s010: The European Union gave the talks a boost as well on Friday by pledging to provide $ 3.6 billion a year over the next three years to help poorer countries adapt to the impact of climate change -- from coping with flood and drought to avoiding deforestation .
semeval2013.d000.s011: Still , Friday featured the same sort of verbal fireworks that have dominated the talks for the past week .
semeval2013.d000.s012: U.S. special climate envoy Todd Stern rejected language requiring binding cuts of greenhouse-gas emissions for industrialized countries compared with voluntary ones by major emerging economies if they were not funded by the developed world .
semeval2013.d000.s013: The move signaled that the Obama administration is taking a harder line with China than Bush administration officials did just two years ago .
semeval2013.d000.s014: The United States is not going to do a deal without the major developing countries stepping up and taking action , said Stern , who also complained that the text did not do enough to make sure the cuts could be verified by outside observers .
semeval2013.d000.s015: Stern made his comments an hour after Chinese vice foreign minister He Yafei said America 's top climate negotiator was either lacking `` common sense '' or being `` extremely irresponsible '' for saying earlier in the week that the United States would not help China financially to cope with global warming .
semeval2013.d000.s016: With the future economic trajectory of the world 's major powers at stake , fault lines have erupted both within the developing world and between the industrial world and emerging economies .
semeval2013.d000.s017: The current battle is as much about saving individual economies as saving the planet , with China and United States feuding over their respective obligations while poorer nations insist that the world 's two dozen most influential countries are ignoring the scientific imperative to take bolder action .
semeval2013.d000.s018: Ricardo Ulate , a Costa Rican delegate , said it 's not surprising that the major powers are fighting over who should bear the costs for curbing greenhouse gases , even as vulnerable countries have become more aggressive in seeking to hold the big emitters accountable for their actions .
semeval2013.d000.s019: This is clearly a game where a new economic hegemony is being developed , said Ulate , who also serves as the regional Mexico and Central America climate change adviser for Conservation International .
semeval2013.d000.s020: Some of the countries most vulnerable to the impact of climate change indicated they would continue to push for a legally binding treaty in Copenhagen , although most of the major participants say the talks will produce a political deal at best .
semeval2013.d000.s021: The Alliance of Small Island States , which has 43 members , produced a 24-page draft treaty proposal early Friday morning .
semeval2013.d000.s022: Artur Runge-Metzger , who heads international climate negotiations on behalf of the European Commission , said the push by small island nations has `` put political pressure on the entire political process , '' in part because they are now unified and demanding action from emerging economies such as China and India .
semeval2013.d000.s023: The talks took on new urgency as delegates focused on the fact that they must resolve most of the outstanding issues before the heads of government arrive to strike a deal .
semeval2013.d000.s024: High-level officials such as Indian environment minister Jairam Ramesh and the Chinese vice minister stepped off planes and raced through the Bella Center 's halls to closed-door meetings and news conferences so they could stake out claims that will be arbitrated over the next week .
semeval2013.d000.s025: The sheer sprawl of the gathering -- where 13,000 people move in and out of the convention center each day , guitar-playing activists put on nightly shows mocking the countries they think are selling out , and draft proposals are passed hand-to-hand on paper rather than via e-mail -- poses a challenge .
semeval2013.d000.s026: The intensity is only building : nearly all of the key ministers are now here , and as early as Wednesday 60 heads of government will be in Copenhagen .
semeval2013.d000.s027: We 're getting into the big leagues , said Carlos Manuel Rodriguez , vice president for global policy at Conservation International .

semeval2013.d003.s002: The 10 deals the Iraqi Oil Ministry reached with foreign oil companies suggest that China , Russia and European oil firms are poised to play a major role in refurbishing Iraq 's oil industry , crippled by decades of war and sanctions .

semeval2013.d005.s000: Cheshire Appeal Will Point to Twitter
semeval2013.d005.s001: There were half a dozen of them typing away in the courtroom rows .
semeval2013.d005.s002: Minute by minute , they sent out reports of gruesome testimony via Twitter .
semeval2013.d005.s003: In the end , the defense says , there were more than 140,000 Twitter messages about the trial that dealt with rape and children tied to their beds in a house that was set ablaze .
semeval2013.d005.s004: On Thursday , the widely followed trial of Steven J. Hayes , who was convicted of killing three members of a Cheshire , Conn. , family , is set to come to an official end with the judge 's imposition of the death sentence voted for by the jury .
semeval2013.d005.s005: But lawyers for Mr. Hayes have already made court filings that sketch out appeals arguments that are likely to occupy the courts for years .
semeval2013.d005.s006: One of the most provocative is that the intense reporting on the trial - including mainstream reporters ' extensive use of Twitter - created a `` circus atmosphere '' and such widespread , instant saturation with inflammatory details that the jury was improperly swayed by public passions .
semeval2013.d005.s007: The claim could force appeals judges to grapple with the question of whether new technology requires new courtroom rules .
semeval2013.d005.s008: `` As I experienced it during this trial , I think there 's a real danger that the inclusion of new technology in the courtroom is affecting an individual 's fair-trial rights , '' said Thomas J. Ullmann , Mr. Hayes 's chief defense lawyer .
semeval2013.d005.s009: The trial judge , Jon C. Blue of State Superior Court , tersely rejected the claims in a ruling last week , saying that the news media were `` carefully controlled '' and that there was no evidence the jury was driven by passion .
semeval2013.d005.s010: But that is not likely to be the last word on the issue .
semeval2013.d005.s011: For decades , appeals courts have recognized that coverage of notorious cases can raise questions about a trial 's fairness .
semeval2013.d005.s012: In a landmark 1966 ruling , the United States Supreme Court overturned the conviction of a Cleveland osteopath , Dr. Sam Sheppard , for the murder of his wife , saying in its decision , Sheppard v. Maxwell , that there was a `` carnival atmosphere at trial '' because of the news media .
semeval2013.d005.s013: The crime is believed by some to have been the inspiration for the television show and the movie `` The Fugitive . ''
semeval2013.d005.s014: Some lawyers said appeals courts reviewing Mr. Hayes 's conviction half a century later might be intrigued by the argument that new rules could be necessary to govern ways of communicating from courtrooms unimagined at the time of Dr. Sheppard 's case .
semeval2013.d005.s015: `` There is a general reason for concern about the impact of the new media '' in high-profile trials , said John J. Donohue III , a Stanford Law School professor who studied the Connecticut death penalty and wrote a report that said it was arbitrarily enforced .
